resources.string: When faced with dilemma at work, many different factors can change the way you choose a solution. In the next page,you will answer questions to discover options available to you.
A safe workplace takes your physical, mental, and emotional safety into consideration. Your safety at work is protected by 3 laws (pieces of legislation):
For more information please contactthe follwing...

The purpose of this app is solely to educate workers about workplace health and safety requlations, general advice and guidance on your rights, and the services available to you. None of this information is intended to be used in a legal way.
The Chatbot features is auto-animated and not an actual person. The chatbot remains exclusive to this app and is an independent feature from the School of Gobal Acess website
Replay the chat anytime to discover different options or skip to read more by tapping on the settings icon in the chats.

Most workers in Alberta are covered under the Alberta Health and Safety Act, Regulation and Code. Some workers such as federal workers, live in care-givers, or farm workers may have their own separate legislation

In addition to workplace safety, hazards, rights and standards, Alberta has legislation that relates to the rights of all people and their dignity, regardless of backgrounds such as ethnocultural group, source of income, participation in a labour union, gender, age, sexual orientation, or immigration status.

Human Rights in Alberta relate to the idea that everyone should be free from discrimination, and apply to employers and workers. Employers cannto sign away their employees human rights. In cases of human rights breaches, specific steps need to be taken. You may read these steps by tapping the button below.
Workers and employers in Alberta are subject to the Employment Standards Code and Employment Standrads Regulation

Employment Standards apply to all workers with a number of exemptions, such as live-in-workers, truckers, farm workers and firefighters. The Employment Standards Code establsihes Albertas minimum standards of employment in areas outside of health and safety that are relevant to the workplace. These include wages, hours of work, overtime, vacation and holidays, leaves and termination of employment. It also establsihes the processes in cases where employment standards have not been met, such as wrongful termination of employment

Most workers in Alberta are protected under the Alberta Health and Safety Act, Regulation and Code. Some workers, such as federal workers, live in care-givers, or farm workers may have their own separate legalisation.\n\n These laws are the minimum standards for protecting workers, and involve both workers and employers.

In addition to workplace safety, hazards, rights, and standards, Alberta has legislation that relates to the rights of all people, regardless of background such as ethnocultural group, source of income, participation in a labour union, gender, age, sexual orientation, or immigration status.
Workers and employers in Alberta must follow the Employment Standards Code and Employment Standards Regulation\n\n

Human Rights in Alberta relate to the idea that everyone should be free from discrimination, and apply to employers and workers. Employers cannot sign away their employees human rights. In cases of human rights breaches ,specific steps need to be taken. You may read these steps by tapping the buttons below:
Employment Standards apply to all the workers with a number of exemptions,such as live- workers, truckers,farm workers and firefighters.

The Employment Standards Code creates Albertaâ€™s minimum standards of employment in areas outside of health and safety that are related to the workplace. These include wages, hours of work, overtime, vacation and holidays, leaves, and termination of employment. It also establishes the steps tp follow in cases where employment standards have not been met, such as wrongful termination of employment.
